home.title: Understand ZK Technology Through
home.description: Explore zk-SNARK and zk-STARK concepts, visualize circuit structures, watch proof generation in real-time, and build a real anonymous voting application.
home.whatYouWillLearnDesc: From theoretical foundations to practical implementation, explore every aspect of Zero-Knowledge proof technology.
home.builtWithModernStackDesc: Using industry-standard tools for ZK development and Web3 integration.
home.readyToExploreDesc: Start with the education modules to understand the fundamentals, then move to visualization and finally build with the demo.

adminControls.title: Admin Controls
adminControls.registerVoterFirst: Register at least one voter before starting the vote.

privacyProblem.title: The Privacy Problem
privacyProblem.description: On a public blockchain, all transactions are visible. If you vote directly, everyone can see who voted for what. This undermines the secret ballot principle.

zkSolution.title: The ZK Solution
zkSolution.description: Zero-knowledge proofs let you prove you are eligible to vote and that your vote is valid, without revealing your identity. The contract only sees a valid proof, not who created it.

step1.title: Deploy Contracts
step1.description: Deploy the ZK verifier and voting contract to Base Sepolia.

step2.title: Register Voters
step2.description: Generate identity secrets and register commitments on-chain.

step3.description: Admin computes Merkle root and starts the voting period.

step4.title: Generate Proof
step4.description: Create a ZK proof showing you know a secret in the Merkle tree.

step5.title: Cast Vote
step5.description: Submit proof + nullifier + vote. Contract verifies and records.

hashPreimage.title: Hash Preimage Proof
hashPreimage.description: Prove you know a secret value that hashes to a known hash, without revealing the secret

intro.title: How Hash Preimage Proofs Work
intro.description: This demo shows the fundamental ZK concept: proving knowledge of a secret that produces a known hash, without revealing the secret itself.

step1.title: Create Hash Commitment
step1.secretHint: This value will never be revealed to the verifier

step2.title: Verify Knowledge
step2.hashHint: This is the public hash that you claim to know the preimage of

result.verifiedDesc: You have proven knowledge of the preimage without revealing it.
result.failedDesc: The provided secret does not match the hash.

step1.title: Hash Your Secret
step1.description: Your secret is hashed using Poseidon, a ZK-friendly hash function.

step2.title: Generate Proof
step2.description: A ZK proof is created showing you know the preimage of the hash.

step3.title: Verify Without Revealing
step3.description: Anyone can verify the proof without learning your secret.

privacy.title: Privacy Guarantee
privacy.description: The verifier learns only that you know a value that hashes to the public hash. They cannot determine what your secret actually is, even with unlimited computational power.

intro.title: Zero-Knowledge Authentication
intro.description: Prove you know your password without sending it to the server. Even a compromised server cannot steal your password.

result.successDesc: Proven: You know the correct password without revealing it.

salted.description: Random salt prevents rainbow table attacks

snark.title: zk-SNARK
snark.subtitle: Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-interactive Argument of Knowledge

overview.description: zk-SNARK stands for Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-interactive Argument of Knowledge. It is a cryptographic proof system that allows one party (the prover) to prove to another party (the verifier) that they know a value x, without conveying any information apart from the fact that they know the value x.

zeroKnowledge.title: Zero-Knowledge
zeroKnowledge.description: The verifier learns nothing except that the statement is true. Your secret remains completely hidden.

succinct.title: Succinct
succinct.description: Proofs are tiny (just a few hundred bytes) and verification is extremely fast, regardless of computation size.

nonInteractive.title: Non-interactive
nonInteractive.description: The prover sends a single message. No back-and-forth communication required between prover and verifier.

argumentOfKnowledge.title: Argument of Knowledge
argumentOfKnowledge.description: The prover must actually know the secret (witness) to generate a valid proof.

howItWorks.title: From Program to Proof
howItWorks.description: zk-SNARKs work by converting your computation into a mathematical form that can be proven and verified. Here is the transformation pipeline:

circuit.title: Arithmetic Circuit
circuit.description: Your computation is expressed as a circuit with gates that perform addition and multiplication.
details: Each gate has input wires and output wires

r1cs.title: R1CS (Rank-1 Constraint System)
r1cs.description: The circuit is flattened into a system of equations in the form A * B = C.
details: Each constraint is a simple multiplication
Variables include public and private inputs
All constraints must be satisfied simultaneously

qap.title: QAP (Quadratic Arithmetic Program)
qap.description: R1CS is transformed into polynomials, enabling efficient verification.

proof.title: Proof Generation
proof.description: The prover uses elliptic curve cryptography to create a compact proof.

trustedSetup.title: The Trusted Setup Ceremony
trustedSetup.description: zk-SNARKs require a one-time trusted setup phase that generates the proving and verification keys. This is both a strength and a potential vulnerability.

whatHappens.title: What Happens
items: Keys are derived from these secrets

toxicWaste.title: The Risk: Toxic Waste
items: If secrets are kept, fake proofs possible

powersOfTau.title: Powers of Tau Ceremony
powersOfTau.description: The most famous trusted setup is the "Powers of Tau" ceremony, used by many ZK projects:

phase1.title: Phase 1: Universal Setup
phase1.description: Many participants contribute randomness sequentially. Each participant adds their own random value.

secureDestruction.title: Secure Destruction
secureDestruction.description: Each participant must destroy their random value after contribution. Various creative destruction methods used.

phase2.title: Phase 2: Circuit-Specific
phase2.description: Additional ceremony for each specific circuit. Smaller and faster than Phase 1.

securityGuarantee.title: Security Guarantee
securityGuarantee.description: As long as at least ONE participant honestly destroyed their random value, the entire ceremony is secure. With hundreds or thousands of participants, this is extremely likely.

tryIt.title: Interactive zk-SNARK Demo
tryIt.description: In this simple demo, you proved knowledge of a number whose square equals the public value. In a real zk-SNARK:
realFeatures: The proof would be cryptographically secure, not just a simulation
The verifier would learn nothing about your secret value
Verification would take only milliseconds regardless of computation complexity
The proof would be only ~200 bytes, verifiable by a smart contract

interactive.startPrompt: Click "Start" to begin the interactive demo
interactive.completeDesc: You have seen all the steps in this process.

simpleProof.title: Simple Proof Demo
simpleProof.description: Prove you know a secret number whose square equals the public value.
simpleProof.claimTemplate: I know x such that x  x = {value}
simpleProof.proofVerified: Proof verified! You know the secret.
simpleProof.proofFailed: Proof failed! The secret is incorrect.

stark.title: zk-STARK
stark.subtitle: Zero-Knowledge Scalable Transparent Argument of Knowledge

overview.description: zk-STARK stands for Zero-Knowledge Scalable Transparent Argument of Knowledge. Developed by StarkWare, STARKs are a newer proof system that addresses some limitations of SNARKs, particularly the need for trusted setup.

scalable.title: Scalable
scalable.description: Proof generation time grows quasi-linearly with computation size, making it efficient for very large computations.

transparent.title: Transparent
transparent.description: No trusted setup required. All randomness comes from public data using hash functions.

quantumResistant.title: Quantum Resistant
quantumResistant.description: Based on hash functions, not elliptic curves. Secure against future quantum computers.

minimalAssumptions.title: Minimal Assumptions
minimalAssumptions.description: Security relies only on collision-resistant hash functions, a well-studied cryptographic primitive.

tradeoffs.title: Trade-offs
items: Larger proof size (tens to hundreds of KB)

howItWorks.title: The STARK Pipeline
howItWorks.description: STARKs use a fundamentally different approach than SNARKs, based on polynomials and hash functions rather than elliptic curves.

air.title: AIR (Algebraic Intermediate Representation)
air.description: Computation is expressed as algebraic constraints over an execution trace.
details: Trace is a table of values at each step
Similar to a spreadsheet with formulas

polynomial.title: Polynomial Commitment
polynomial.description: The execution trace is encoded as polynomials using Reed-Solomon encoding.
details: Polynomials are evaluated on a larger domain

fri.title: FRI Protocol (Fast Reed-Solomon IOP)
fri.description: A clever protocol to prove that committed values are actually low-degree polynomials.
details: Uses random challenges from hash of transcript

fiatShamir.title: Fiat-Shamir Transform
fiatShamir.description: Converts interactive proof to non-interactive using hash functions.

example.title: AIR Example: Fibonacci
example.description: To prove knowledge of the 100th Fibonacci number:

transparency.title: Transparent Setup
transparency.description: One of the most significant advantages of STARKs is that they require no trusted setup. All the randomness used in the protocol is derived publicly.

comparisonToSnarks.title: Comparison to SNARKs
items: Ceremony must be done per circuit

postQuantum.title: Post-Quantum Security
postQuantum.description: STARKs are considered quantum-resistant because they rely only on hash functions, not elliptic curve cryptography.

futureProofing.title: Future-Proofing
futureProofing.description: While quantum computers capable of breaking elliptic curve cryptography do not exist yet, many organizations are already planning for post-quantum security. STARKs provide this security today.

applications.title: Real-World STARK Applications
applications.description: STARKs are being used in production by several major projects, particularly in the blockchain scaling space.

starknet.title: StarkNet
starknet.description: A decentralized Layer 2 network powered by STARKs

whenToUse.title: When to Use STARKs vs SNARKs

starks.title: Choose STARKs When:
items: Proof size is not a constraint

comparison.title: SNARK vs STARK
comparison.subtitle: A comprehensive comparison of the two major zero-knowledge proof systems
comparison.snarkDesc: Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-interactive Argument of Knowledge
comparison.starkDesc: Zero-Knowledge Scalable Transparent Argument of Knowledge

onChain.title: On-chain verification
onChain.description: When gas costs matter, smaller proofs save money

identity.title: Identity systems
identity.description: Where proof size and verification speed are critical

tooling.title: Existing tooling
tooling.description: Projects that need mature libraries (Circom, snarkjs)

noTrust.title: No trust requirements
noTrust.description: When eliminating trusted setup is essential

future.title: The Future: Hybrid Approaches
future.description: The ZK space is rapidly evolving, and the distinction between SNARKs and STARKs is becoming less clear-cut. Several promising developments:

starkSnarkWrapping.title: STARK + SNARK Wrapping
starkSnarkWrapping.description: Use STARKs for proving, then wrap in a SNARK for cheap on-chain verification. Best of both worlds.

universalSnarks.title: Universal SNARKs
universalSnarks.description: Systems like PLONK require only a single trusted setup for all circuits, reducing the setup burden.

recursiveProofs.title: Recursive Proofs
recursiveProofs.description: Both systems can recursively verify proofs, enabling infinite computation scaling.

bottomLine.title: Bottom Line
bottomLine.description: Both SNARKs and STARKs are powerful tools. The choice depends on your specific requirements around proof size, verification cost, setup requirements, and security assumptions. Many production systems use both.

circuit.title: Circuit Visualization
circuit.description: Explore how Circom circuits are structured with signals, constraints, and templates
circuit.graphDescription: Select a circuit from the dropdown to visualize its structure. Click on nodes to see details. Drag to pan, scroll to zoom.
circuit.signalsDescription: Signals are the variables in a Circom circuit. They carry values through the computation.
circuit.inputSignalsDesc: Values provided by the prover. Can be public (visible to verifier) or private (hidden).
circuit.outputSignalsDesc: Computed values that become public. The verifier sees these.
circuit.intermediateSignalsDesc: Internal values used during computation. Not directly visible.
circuit.constraintsTemplatesDesc: Constraints define the rules that signals must satisfy. Templates are reusable circuit components.
circuit.constraintsDesc: Equations that must be satisfied. Form: A * B + C = 0. The prover must find values that satisfy all constraints.
circuit.templatesDesc: Reusable circuit components like Poseidon hash or Merkle tree checkers. Compose to build complex circuits.

proof.title: Proof Process Visualization
proof.description: Watch how zero-knowledge proofs are generated and verified step by step

hiddenItems.secrets: Any secrets used in the proof

proof.piADesc: First element of the Groth16 proof. An elliptic curve point in G1.
proof.piBDesc: Second element. An elliptic curve point in G2 (larger).
proof.piCDesc: Third element. Another G1 point completing the proof.
proof.verificationDescription: Groth16 verification checks a pairing equation:
proof.verificationExplanation: If this equation holds, the proof is valid. The verifier is convinced the prover knows the witness without seeing it.

witness.name: Compute Witness
witness.description: Execute circuit to compute all intermediate values

proof.name: Generate Proof
proof.description: Create cryptographic proof using witness and proving key

verify.name: Verify Proof
verify.description: Verify the proof against public inputs

proofVerified.title: Proof Verified Successfully!
proofVerified.description: The zero-knowledge proof has been generated and verified. The verifier is convinced of the statement without learning the secret.

comparison.chartNote: Note: Values are shown on a logarithmic scale for better visualization of the differences. Boolean values (Setup Required, Quantum Safe) are shown as Yes/No.

proofSize.description: SNARKs produce much smaller proofs, crucial for on-chain verification costs.

verificationTime.description: SNARK verification is faster, though both are practical for most applications.

proverTime.description: STARKs scale better with computation size due to quasi-linear complexity.

trustedSetup.description: STARKs eliminate the need for trusted ceremonies entirely.

quantumResistance.description: STARKs are secure against quantum computers; SNARKs are not.

ecosystemMaturity.description: SNARKs have been around longer with more tools and documentation.

footer.builtFor: Built for learning ZK technology. Open source on
